item.title: Mapping Twitter Topics and Sentiment about FAAMG Companies since Covid-19 Outbreak
item.description:
• 1 Motivation
  • 2 Procedures
    • 2.1 Data Source
    • 2.2 Topic Modeling
  • 3 Results
    • 3.1 Perceptual Map of FAAMG Based on Topic Sentiment
    • 3.2 Keywords Co-occurrence Network on Each Topic

1 Motivation

On a whim, I mapped out what people say (the text) and feel (the sentiment) about the top tech companies (FAAMG) on twitter since the Covid-19 outbreak. The keywords and sentiment that are associated with the main topics should differ across these companies.

By no means I am drawing any causal association here. But the story starts with checking the recent price movements of the FAAMG stocks. But obviously Covid-19 has impacted these companies quite differently.

2 Procedures

2.1 Data Source

For each company, I downloaded 1,000 tweets containing the company name as the hashtag (e.g. “#amazon” for Amazon). I used Python module “tweepy” to stream the data and set the “since” parameter to ‘2020-03-01’, which collects a sample of 1,000 tweets since March 1st.

2.2 Topic Modeling

Using Python module “gensim”, I detected three most significant topics (including Covid-19, business, and daily life), which are named by the associated keywords (most relevant terms). Using Python module “vaderSentiment”, I computed sentiment scores for each tweet and aggregated the scores by company. The topic-based sentiment scores are used to construct the perceptual map, in which each company takes a different position. Using Python module “nltk”, I find the most frequent topic-based co-occurring words for each company.

3 Results

3.1 Perceptual Map of FAAMG Based on Topic Sentiment

It looks Amazon does well on all topics, especially on Covid-19-related topic. Microsoft and Apple do well on “Business”.

item.title: My Current Research
item.description:
My research investigates how strategic actions are both “embedded in” and “reconstructive to” the social structure of the market, and how the “action-structure” co-evolution drives firm performance.

My work mostly falls into the topics of Mergers and Acquisitions (M&As), Market Categories, and Interfirm Network. Currently, I am working with John Haleblian (dissertation chair), Gerry McNamara, Ming Leung, and Jun Xia.

Dissertation chapters:

  • Achieving Optimal Positioning through Acquisitions
    (an earlier AOM paper, nominated for the 2019 SMS Best PhD Paper)
  • The Extra-dyadic Impact of Acquisitions on Acquirer Alliance Partners
    (included in the 2019 AOM Best Paper Proceedings)
